Astarion: I'd hate to get between the gith and her trophy. No, I think we'll end this evening as friends.
Player: Are you offering anything better? Because I could be persuaded...
Astarion: Let's wait until things quieten down a bit. Once the others are asleep, we'll find each other.
Player: On second thought, maybe we'd better not.

Karlach: InternalNodeContext: Companion confronts Avatar Astarion, telling him they know he's a vampire. Triggers if you make it to Act 2 without him telling you himself or revealing it via camp night bite scene/using bite attack in front of you.
Karlach: Hey, soldier.
Player: Did you really think I wouldn't notice you here, devil?

Karlach: If you'd just hear me out -
Narrator: *A great fire roars through you - the fire of the First Hell.*
Narrator: *Her rage and desperation seep into you. She is a victim of the Blood War, not an agent of it.*
Karlach: Fuck. I'll never get used to that.
Karlach: Look, whatever else it may be, the tadpole isn't a liar. I never wanted to serve Zariel, and I escaped the first chance I could. So stand down.
NodeContext: Ready for a fight if needed.
Shadowheart: Let's take things down a notch, shall we? She's no devil, Wyll. You'll have to look elsewhere to find fodder for your blade.
Player: You don't know what this means. You don't know what you're asking me to do.
Karlach: I'm asking you to live, Wyll. I don't want to hurt you. And, to be frank, I'd rather not find out how the Blade got his name.
Karlach: I swear to you, on all I am, I'm not what you think.
Narrator: *Two souls hang in the balance. Kill Karlach, fulfil your contract - and condemn a possible innocent to the Hells. Or spare her and face the repercussions with Mizora.*
Player: I'm sorry, Karlach. There's too much at stake.

Karlach: Copper for your thoughts?
Karlach: Hey, soldier.
Player: Did you really think I wouldn't notice you here, devil?
Karlach: Well I'll be godsdamned - the Blade of Frontiers. Thought I'd shaken you for good. That'll teach me to underestimate you.
Karlach: Look - it's an honour to be chased by a famed hero. I'm no devil, though. Not by a long shot.
Player: I've hunted you to the Hells and beyond. It ends here, Karlach.
Karlach: For fuck's sake, you must be half troll to have a skull that thick.
Karlach: If you'd just hear me out -
Narrator: *A great fire roars through you - the fire of the First Hell.*
Narrator: *Her rage and desperation seep into you. She is a victim of the Blood War, not an agent of it.*
Karlach: Fuck. I'll never get used to that.
Karlach: Look, whatever else it may be, the tadpole isn't a liar. I never wanted to serve Zariel, and I escaped the first chance I could. So stand down.
NodeContext: Ready for a fight if needed.
Shadowheart: Let's take things down a notch, shall we? She's no devil, Wyll. You'll have to look elsewhere to find fodder for your blade.
Player: How can I make peace with the monster I was sent to kill?
Karlach: You know monsters, right? Better than anyone. Look into my eyes. Can't you see I'm not what you think?
Narrator: *Two souls hang in the balance. Kill Karlach, fulfil your contract - and condemn a possible innocent to the Hells. Or spare her and face the repercussions with Mizora.*
Player: Save your breath. Let's see if this devil bleeds.

Gondian Zanner Toobin: Take the city - let the Ironhands reign supreme. I just wish to go home and mourn my daughter in peace.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Take the city - let the Ironhands reign supreme. I just wish to go home, and to hold my daughter.

("safe houses" as in "safehouses" for shelter)
Wulbren Bongle: Please - if a Gondian told me the sky was blue, I'd look outside and check.
Wulbren Bongle: You Gondians will lie, scheme, and torment this city until your dying breaths. Let's end this.

Barcus Wroot: Kill Toobin, and you kill all we love: Collaboration. Challenge. Solving problems with the power of reason, creativity, and invention.
Barcus Wroot: I still want to believe you're better than that, Wulbren. But even I am having my doubts.
Player: Sorry, Toobin - I guess this is it for you.

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic.
Halsin: Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: Glad I could be of help.
Halsin: I must admit, I didn't expect anyone would come to my aid. Who in their right mind would infiltrate a goblin infested temple. Unless...
Halsin: ...Hrrm. That look in your eyes - I've seen it before. Are you feeling all right?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn.
Halsin: But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
Halsin: How is this possible...?
Player: I think this artefact has something to do with it.
Halsin: Hmmm... that looks very alien. As alien as the mind flayers. They do not belong on this world.
Halsin: You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know.
Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: You learned all this from your studies?
Halsin: Indeed. After we dealt with the drow that ambushed us, Nettie and I were able to inspect the corpse - and the creature that slithered out of it.
Halsin: I had no idea anyone beyond their ranks was infected. You have my sincere sympathies.
Player: What should I do?
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.
Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: You seem to know a lot about this. Will you come with me to Moonrise?
Halsin: I wish I could, but there's still work I've yet to finish - blood I've yet to spill.
Halsin: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
Halsin: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: Look around you - there's no order anymore. Only chaos.
Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural.
Halsin: It's too late to merely kill this horde's leadership - their forces are already marching. If you want me to help, you need to help me first.
Halsin: You must get ahead of them, muster the defences.
Player: Very well. I'll go rescue the grove.

Karlach: Well I'll be godsdamned - the Blade of Frontiers. Thought I'd shaken you for good. That'll teach me to underestimate you.
Karlach: Look - it's an honour to be chased by a famed hero. I'm no devil, though. Not by a long shot.
Player: You fight in the Blood War for Zariel. You'll bring the Blood War to the Coast.
Karlach: Yeah, I stowed away on a mind flayer ship so I could bring the war home. Makes perfect sense.
Karlach: If you'd just hear me out -
Narrator: *A great fire roars through you - the fire of the First Hell.*
Narrator: *Her rage and desperation seep into you. She is a victim of the Blood War, not an agent of it.*
Karlach: Fuck. I'll never get used to that.
Karlach: Look, whatever else it may be, the tadpole isn't a liar. I never wanted to serve Zariel, and I escaped the first chance I could. So stand down.
NodeContext: Ready for a fight if needed.
Lae'zel: Control yourself, Wyll. I understand bloodthirst. But this is no time to quench it.
Shadowheart: Let's take things down a notch, shall we? She's no devil, Wyll. You'll have to look elsewhere to find fodder for your blade.
Player: You don't know what this means. You don't know what you're asking me to do.
Karlach: I'm asking you to live, Wyll. I don't want to hurt you. And, to be frank, I'd rather not find out how the Blade got his name.
Karlach: I swear to you, on all I am, I'm not what you think.
Narrator: *Two souls hang in the balance. Kill Karlach, fulfil your contract - and condemn a possible innocent to the Hells. Or spare her and face the repercussions with Mizora.*
Player: I'm sorry, Karlach. There's too much at stake.

Raphael: Do you know what happens when a devil is struck down on this charming plane of existence?
Raphael: It returns to the hells - to the very point where it last stood before venturing to whichever devilforsaken plane it died on.
Raphael: In the case of our friend Yurgir, the orthon you so handily dispatched in the temple of Shar, he manifested in my House of Hope.
Raphael: He returned to me chastened but intact, his wounds healed, his body restored.
Raphael: He thought I would dismember him but he has his uses so instead I am reeducating him.
Astarion: We delivered the devil. Now I want what I'm owed - we had a deal.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: We had a deal - the orthon for information.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: We had a deal - the orthon for information.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: We had a deal - the orthon for information.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: Please, give me more boring details about your plans.
Raphael: Come now, we're about to unveil your destiny - you should be quivering in anticipation.

Raphael: And why would he want to walk away? This is his destiny.
Raphael: As you know already, your precious skin is home to one part of a contract between the archdevil Mephistopheles, and your former master, Cazador Szarr.
Raphael: In full, the contract states that Cazador will be granted knowledge of an infernal ritual so vile it has never been performed.
Raphael: The Rite of Profane Ascension.
Raphael: It promises to be a marvellous ceremony. Very elaborate, incredibly ancient, and entirely diabolical.
Raphael: If he completes the rite, he will become a new kind of being - the Vampire Ascendant.
Raphael: All the strengths of his vampiric form will be amplified, and alongside them he will enjoy the luxuries of the living.
Raphael: The arousals and appetites of man will return to him, and unlike Astarion, he will have no need of a parasite to protect him from the sun.
Raphael: But the ritual has its price, as all worthwhile things do. Lord Cazador will need to sacrifice a number of souls, including all of his vampiric spawn, if he is to ascend.
Raphael: Imagine how he felt, then, when one of those precious spawn simply disappeared into thin air.
Raphael: The only missing ingredient is Astarion.
Raphael: You are the final piece he requires to complete the ritual - your scars bind you to it. Your soul will set off a very wave of death, bringing Cazador his twisted life.
Raphael: And that, my tragic and toothsome friend, is that. Now if you'll excuse me, I have business elsewhere.
NodeContext: [Tarik] snaps fingers at the end of the line.
Astarion: Hmm...
Player: 'Hmm'? That's all you have to say?
Astarion: I was... contemplating. It's a lot to take in.
Astarion: What do you think I should do?
Player: We can't let Cazador complete that ritual. He could unleash terrible horrors.
Astarion: The end of my life among them. Just when I was starting to enjoy it.
Astarion: He'll never leave me alone. I didn't think he would when I was just one more wretched toy for him to play with.
Astarion: But if I'm the key to this power he craves, he'll hunt me to the ends of Faerûn.
Astarion: I need to take the fight to him.
Astarion: And I need you to help me.
Player: After we dealt with our tadpole problem, yes, I'll help you then.
Astarion: Once we deal with the tadpole, I'll be back to my nocturnal self. When you're being hunted by vampires, the dark is the worst place to hide.
Astarion: I need to deal with Cazador while I still have any kind of advantage over him.
Astarion: If you won't risk taking him on for my sake, think of the innocent souls he'll sacrifice in this ritual.
Player: The Absolute is a greater threat - we need to focus.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: May Shar guide your blessing hands.
Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours.
Malus Thorm: Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Precisely.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Astarion: He's just like Cazador - utterly insane.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure.
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The goddess has greater plans for me than to submit to your scalpels.
: True
Malus Thorm: Another absence is your fate? But if you are not here to be cured, how will my sisters learn?
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Sparring is vital to progress. Have them practice on each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
: True
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

Sarevok Anchev: You stand now on the cusp of the Dread Lord's favour.
Sarevok Anchev: You have proven capable of killing those known to you, but true devotion is the killing of an innocent. One who never had reason to wrong you.
Sarevok Anchev: One who dies for no other reason than the sanctity of slaughter.
Sarevok Anchev: Kill this celestial being, make violence of its goodness, and you will be reborn - an Unholy Assassin of Bhaal.
Sarevok Anchev: Make violence of its goodness. Spill its blood, and bathe in Bhaal's eternal rapture.
Valeria: Civilian, do not listen to this ancient fuck. Free me at once.
Shadowheart: This is Bhaal's sacrifice...? Wouldn't have been my first guess. Or my tenth.
Player: It shall play a symphony of screams with its trumpet!

Havkelaag: Ah, a fellow inhabitor of the Underdark.
Havkelaag: You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to our subterranean home: the Society of Brilliance.
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You yourself have no doubt experienced the prejudice of those who assume that, as beings of the Underdark, we are inherently evil.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You assume my people are evil, yet your research is built on sheer superstition.
Havkelaag: Enough of your kind have wreaked destruction on this plane for me to be confident in my assertion.
Havkelaag: When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: Why follow the dogma of a draconic god?
Havkelaag: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: And what if your experiment fails?
Havkelaag: If the child remains evil after the experiment is concluded, it will be destroyed. Such is the fate of all used specimens.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.
Havkelaag: Ah. Unfortunately, it seems I've mislaid my purse.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?
Player: Fine. Here you go.

Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: My ardents spoke of one of our kin that escaped a crashing ghaik slave-vessel.
Lae'zel: Ch'r'ai. Vlaakith's justice in flesh.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You have accomplished much, child. I am pleased to finally meet you.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You have accomplished much since. I am pleased to finally meet you.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I heard there is so much goblin blood on your hands that it soaks their children's nightmares.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Kith'rak Voss' made a mistake when he let you go.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: To business. I suspect you plucked something precious from the ghaik ship. Something that belongs to us.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: The weapon. Give it to me.
Narrator: *The artefact stirs in your pocket. Right within your grasp, and desperate not to be relinquished.*
GROUP_Daisy: Don't do it. The weapon is how I protect you.
Lae'zel: Do it. Do not disobey the Inquisitor.
Player: I can't. It protects me.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Indeed? And what does it protect you from?
Player: All kinds of bad things. It's my lucky charm.
: True
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You really have no idea what it is, do you?
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: But you were not wrong to observe that you need protection.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Once the Grand Design comes into effect and the Illithid Empire is restored, all life will be over as you know it.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: We took an interest in you when you became involved with this 'Absolute' cult. A pestilence of infected slaves - the first symptom of the Grand Design in action.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: But you are lucky - that weapon you carry is the solution. I have heard it from Queen Vlaakith herself.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Hand it over.
Player: What do I get in return if I give it to you?
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: The ghaik are about to execute their Grand Design and you seek to bargain. P'hak'va.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: The weapon. Now.
Player: What is the Grand Design?
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: The Grand Design is what all ghaik seek. The restoration of the Illithid Empire, which spanned the entirety of the multiverse.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: For centuries, their elder brains sought to bring back their dominion. Every plot they hatched, we stopped. But now, they are close to succeeding.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Never before could they pause ceremorphosis. Never before could they let the infection spread undetected.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Imagine that everywhere. Wants, needs, choice - all would cease to be.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Everything rendered unto the ghaik.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: So. The weapon. Please.
GROUP_Daisy: Don't give it to him.
Player: I won't let you take it.
Lae'zel: Do not try me. Hand over the artefact, or die by my hand.
NodeContext: Threatening and confident. She means what she says.
Player: Remember the zaith'isk? These gith can't be trusted. Follow my lead - I'll choose the right path.

Narrator: *Your father, once the Grand Duke, now a pawn in the Absolute's game. Your infected minds smoulder in each others' presence.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: My dearest boy. The Hells have touched you. But you've come to me - just as Gortash said you would.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Father and son, unstoppable generals. Together, we will usher in a new dawn.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Have you come to behold the new dawn?
Player: I'm here to help you. Florrick sent me.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Help me? Ah - the black widow caught you in her web.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Florrick chose shadow over light. Her betrayal burned deeper than the fires of Avernus.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: She's been punished for her lies. Don't let her get to you.
Narrator: *The Duke wants to keep Florrick's location a secret. Little does he know that you've already found and freed her.*
Player: Connect with Ravengard's parasite to seek information about Florrick.
: True
Narrator: *Within Ravengard's memories, you find Counsellor Florrick. She is confined in a cell, right here in Wyrm's Rock.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: The sun rises, True Soul. Are you ready?
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Have you come to behold the new dawn?
Player: I'm here to help you. Florrick sent me.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Help me? Ah - the black widow caught you in her web.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Florrick chose shadow over light. Her betrayal burned deeper than the fires of Avernus.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: She's been punished for her lies. Don't let her get to you.
Shadowheart: Punished? Florrick must be locked up somewhere - assuming she's still alive.
Player: What have you done to Florrick?
Duke Ulder Ravengard: The sun rises, True Soul. Are you ready?
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Have you come to behold the new dawn?
Player: By the gods, what have they made of the city's great hero?
Duke Ulder Ravengard: What is a hero, if not an actor for the greater good?
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Faerûn suffers in darkness. Tyr has abandoned us; Helm's eye has strayed.
Narrator: *Tyr's fury glows within you. Despite Ravengard's words, the Lord of Justice has remained loyal to you, as you have to him.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: But Baldur's Gate will soon burn bright. A beacon to light the heavens.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Gortash and I will ignite the final spark. And that, True Soul, is the greatest of goods.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Have you come to behold the new dawn?
Player: 'New dawn'? Is that what you call the tyranny the Absolute brings to Baldur's Gate?

Karlach: Ah! A circus! Can we go?!
Player: Is now the time for a circus? The army of the Absolute is close.
Klaus: Well, when we zapped in, we didn't know there were religious zealots marching on the city. Slight inconvenience, that. But they're no threat to us.
Klaus: The Absolute's little murderers wouldn't dare.
Klaus: Benji here checks all our patrons to make sure none of you are vicious murderers. Can't be too careful!
Klaus: Hello, hello, and welcome to the Circus of the Last Days - the finest extraplanar circus there is!
Karlach: Ah! A circus! Can we go?!
Narrator: *This entire place practically vibrates with a familiar, excitable magic. You feel your patron giggle from afar - it's fey magic.*
Player: Are there a lot of murderers around?
Klaus: You haven't heard? The Absolute's cronies have been busy chopping people up like it's going out of style.
Klaus: They won't go near us, of course - Lucretious, Bringer of Night, protects us.
Klaus: And even the Absolute knows better than to tangle with a necromancer.
Klaus: Benji here checks all our patrons to make sure none of you are vicious murderers. Can't be too careful!
Klaus: Hello, hello, and welcome to the Circus of the Last Days - the finest extraplanar circus there is!
Karlach: Ah! A circus! Can we go?!
Narrator: *This entire place practically vibrates with a familiar, excitable magic. You feel your patron giggle from afar - it's fey magic.*
Player: Are there a lot of murderers around?
Klaus: You haven't heard? The Absolute's cronies have been busy chopping people up like it's going out of style.
Klaus: They won't go near us, of course - Lucretious, Bringer of Night, protects us.
Klaus: And even the Absolute knows better than to tangle with a necromancer.
Klaus: Benji here checks all our patrons to make sure none of you are vicious murderers. Can't be too careful!
Klaus: But enough of this - the circus is a place of joy and distraction! So come inside and forget your worries.
Player: All right - I'd like to enter the circus.
Klaus: Not a problem, dear patron! Benji just has to check if you're a vicious murderer. Benji!
Benji: *Sniff.* Huh. *Sniff.* *SNIFF.*
Klaus: That's a first. Usually I'd allow you in, but in these times I can take no chances. Move along - no circus for you.
Narrator: *You feel your patron bristle with a thousand briars at the rejection. It places some barbed words on your tongue - a weapon, should you need it.*
Player: You can smell the blood of my enemies, that is all. Want to join my scent?
Player: Let me in, or I snap you in two.

Gerringothe Thorm: YOU BROUGHT VIOLENCE. UNACCEPTABLE. BUT ALL CAN BE FORGIVEN. FOR THE RIGHT PRICE.
Gerringothe Thorm: WHAT DO YOU BRING?
NodeContext: a desperate, cacophonous howl
Player: What do you require?
Gerringothe Thorm: I REQUIRE GOLD.
NodeContext: Roared with a shudder of pleasure on 'GOLD'.
Player: Leave.
Gerringothe Thorm: YOU CANNOT LEAVE. YOU MUST PAY.
Gerringothe Thorm: I REQUIRE GOLD.
NodeContext: Roared with a shudder of pleasure on 'GOLD'.
Player: Leave.
Gerringothe Thorm: YOU CANNOT LEAVE. YOU MUST PAY.
Gerringothe Thorm: I REQUIRE GOLD.
NodeContext: Roared with a shudder of pleasure on 'GOLD'.

[description] NodeContext: The player tosses a gold piece to the creature. Gerringothe absorbs the gold
Gerringothe Thorm: I REQUIRE MORE!
Player: Leave.
Gerringothe Thorm: YOU CANNOT LEAVE. YOU MUST PAY.
Gerringothe Thorm: I REQUIRE GOLD.
NodeContext: Roared with a shudder of pleasure on 'GOLD'.
Player: Toss the creature a gold piece.
[description] NodeContext: The player tosses a gold piece to the creature. Gerringothe absorbs the gold
Gerringothe Thorm: I REQUIRE MORE!
Player: I don't hand out so much gold for so little in return.
Gerringothe Thorm: YOU MAY PASS THE RIVER. BUT FIRST YOU MUST PAY.
Player: I've already paid.
Gerringothe Thorm: YES! AGAIN!
Player: You're corrupt. I don't take kindly to such tactics.
: True
Gerringothe Thorm: CORRUPTION - NO! GOLD - I NEED GOLD!
Player: It's over. Stand down. Now.
: True
Gerringothe Thorm: STAND... DOWN? BUT... GOLD.
Gerringothe Thorm: NO. I PAY IT BACK!

Alfira: You're all right! Thank goodness, I was worried they'd got you too.
NodeContext: Relieved. Trying to be cheerful but you're upset, and just holding it together.
Player: I heard what happened - that people were taken to Moonrise.
Alfira: I keep replaying it... over and over in my head.
Alfira: We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them.
Alfira: They lined us up like dogs. Asharak was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right.
Alfira: Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel...
Alfira: They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: Wandering into the darkness was a stupid idea.
Alfira: And I regret it with every breath.
Alfira: Rolan, of all people, saved us.
Alfira: He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: You're lucky to be alive.
Alfira: I don't feel lucky. I feel... I feel like I'm at the end of my rope.
Alfira: How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: Danger is my life - I wouldn't change it for the world.
Alfira: You're made of sterner stuff than me then.
Alfira: You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there.
Alfira: If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: Don't worry, I'll find them.

Wulbren Bongle: You ordered that guard about as if you were the Absolute herself. What do you want with us, exactly?
Player: I could help you get out of here - for a price.
Wulbren Bongle: Were I to get such help, I'd be appreciative. But why would a True Soul be offering?
Wulbren Bongle: Huh. And why would you be so inclined?
Player: I'm an undercover agent for the Flaming Fist.

Narrator: *The gnomes speak in soft whispers, the words all but lost in the hot air.*
Player: Eavesdrop on the conversation.
: True
Lunkbug: We'll never get through. We need that smokepowder.
NodeContext: Whispered
Apprentice Laridda: Philomeen's gone. And if she's smart, she won't be coming back.
NodeContext: Whispered
Lunkbug: Beldron's trapped with that maniac Nere. If you won't find Philomeen, I will.
NodeContext: Whispered
Apprentice Laridda: Forget the smokepowder - there could be more slavers out there. You'd draw them right to her!
NodeContext: Whispered
Apprentice Laridda: Forget the smokepowder - they'd kill Phil on the spot. I won't let you do it.
NodeContext: Whispered
Player: Listen - I can help you. Act frightened, or you'll draw suspicion.
: True
Lunkbug: Praise Ironhand. Laridda - our prayers are answered!
Lunkbug: Hear me out - our friends are trapped in the cave-in. And I know a way to get them out.
Apprentice Laridda: Bug, please. True Soul Nere will - you know what he'll do.

Wyll and Karlach stand facing one another, fists clenched.

Shadowheart: You two have met before, I take it?

Karlach: Look - it's an honour to be chased by a famed hero. I'm no devil, though. Not by a long shot.
Wyll: You fight in the Blood War for Zariel. You'll bring the Blood War to the Coast.
Karlach: Yeah, I stowed away on a mind flayer ship so I could bring the war home. Makes perfect sense.
Karlach: If you'd just hear me out -
Narrator: *A great fire roars through you - the fire of the First Hell.*
Narrator: *Her rage and desperation seep into you. She is a victim of the Blood War, not an agent of it.*
Karlach: Fuck. I'll never get used to that.
Karlach: Look, whatever else it may be, the tadpole isn't a liar. I never wanted to serve Zariel, and I escaped the first chance I could. So stand down.
NodeContext: Ready for a fight if needed.
Gale: Easy, Wyll. She's no devil. There's no fight to be had here.

Wyll: You don't know what this means. You don't know what you're asking me to do.
Karlach: I'm asking you to live, Wyll. I don't want to hurt you. And, to be frank, I'd rather not find out how the Blade got his name.
Karlach: I swear to you, on all I am, I'm not what you think.
Narrator: *Two souls hang in the balance. Kill Karlach, fulfil your contract - and condemn a possible innocent to the Hells. Or spare her and face the repercussions with Mizora.*
Wyll: It will mean my undoing, but... I believe you.

Wulbren Bongle: Good to see you. Wasn't sure you'd make it to the city. Regretting it yet?
Wulbren Bongle: I spent a lot of time thinking of worst case scenarios while I was locked in that cell you plucked me out of at Moonrise.
Wulbren Bongle: I didn't imagine anything as bad as this. The Gondians have handed Enver Gortash the means to bring about the end of liberty in Baldur's Gate.
Wulbren Bongle: And the citizens have rolled out the red carpet for their new tyrant.
Wulbren Bongle: Resistance fighters are few and far between - my Ironhands, what's left of the Harpers, and you. I hope.
Player: I'm with you.
Wulbren Bongle: Good. We don't have a chance unless we stick together - not while the Gondians' metal monsters are patrolling the streets.
Wulbren Bongle: The Steel Watch. They're a threat to you, me - and every man, woman and child in the city.
Wulbren Bongle: They act all civilised... servants of the people. But they only serve one man.
Wulbren Bongle: When he becomes Grand Duke, it will only get worse. Laws will change, freedoms will vanish, and soon you'll be accused and sentenced before you've even committed a crime.
Wulbren Bongle: And the fucking Gondians are to blame for all of it.
Player: The Gondians are just inventors. You can't blame them for Gortash's actions.
Wulbren Bongle: I can blame them for precisely that reason.
Player: There must be a reason the Gondians would do something so terrible.
Wulbren Bongle: Could be they're part of the cult. Could just be for coin. Couldn't possibly tell you.
Wulbren Bongle: They've always been happy to provide their technology to despots in exchange for a stipend and the freedom to work in peace.
Wulbren Bongle: They would have licked Sarevok's boots given the chance, and now they'll kiss Gortash's ring while the city screams.
Wulbren Bongle: I had a plan to put a stop to them. But the way things are now, if we stick our heads above ground, the Watchers are on us like flies on shit.
Player: I've already run foul of the Watchers myself.
Wulbren Bongle: And yet here you are, all in one piece. Most people who cross them aren't much more than a stain on the street afterwards.
Wulbren Bongle: You can do what's needed - I'm sure of it.
Wulbren Bongle: You just need a little assistance, and I can provide it.
Wulbren Bongle: The Gondians are ingenious. But we're more than equal to them - there's nothing they can build that the Ironhands can't tear down.
Wulbren Bongle: I've built something unique for just that purpose.
Wulbren Bongle: A runepowder bomb - first of its kind. Fifty wizards high on the Weave couldn't summon this kind of firepower.
Wulbren Bongle: Get the bomb inside the Gondian facility, and - boom. Problem solved.
Barcus Wroot: Wulbren, please. This is too far! Everyone in the foundry would be killed.
Wulbren Bongle: Quiet, Barcus. The adults are talking.
Player: I'll blow up the foundry - give me the bomb.

Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. Your kind have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: Most on this plane believe you to be innately cruel, violent beings. Evil, if you will.
Havkelaag: As citizens of the Underdark, we face similar stigmas. Totally unfounded, of course - our natures are as unfixed as any who walk the surface.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: What does this 'intellectually stimulating' upbringing look like?
Havkelaag: In the literal sense, I will need to induce the egg to hatch via the application of certain currents to the creature inside.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: Why follow the dogma of a draconic god?
Havkelaag: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Your findings are irrelevant, as are the opinions of all on this kaincha plane.
Havkelaag: Ah. A display of the well-known githyanki arrogance. I am not sure my experiment can cure that particular affliction, but give me time and I will find a way.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.
Havkelaag: Ah. Unfortunately, it seems I've mislaid my purse.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?
Player: Fine. Here you go.

Rugan: By the gods, you're a sweet sight.
Rugan: Are any of my crew still alive out there?
Player: No. It's a grim sight.
Rugan: This whole journey's been one grim sight after another. Gnolls, goblins... drow.
Rugan: Risen Road's more dangerous than ever. You're the first friendly face we've seen since Elturgard.
Player: Elturgard's a long way from here. Where are you heading?
Rugan: We're bound for Baldur's Gate - got some cargo to deliver. But we've a stop to make along the way.
Player: Where's that?
Rugan: Waukeen's Rest. It's just up the road. I'd be enjoying a mug of ale right now if those beasts hadn't jumped us.
Rugan: Listen. You look like you know how to handle yourself.
Rugan: You should meet my associates. We've got our own drinking spot by the tavern - invitation only.
Rugan: Tell the fellow on the door 'little serpent, long shadow'. He'll take good care of you.
Olly: Rugan!

: True

Rugan: It's fine. We'd be dead if they hadn't showed up. A little hospitality won't do any harm.
Player: What's in the chest? Your cargo?
Rugan: Aye. The whole reason we're in this mess. Trinkets for some rich tosser in Baldur's Gate.
Rugan: He gets his shiny baubles, we get a handful of Tarenths.

Player: You're Zhentarim. Your people don't deal in 'baubles'.
Rugan: You know who we are - very clever. Then you probably also know it's not smart to interfere with Zhent business.
Rugan: This is the point when a clever operator like you accepts my gratitude and walks away.
Player: You'll find I'm very persuasive. We can make much more coin than you would with your employers.
: True
Rugan: I like the way you think. Didn't expect to turn this horrorshow to my advantage... but why not?
Rugan: The chest's all yours. Damn thing's sealed tighter than a Duke's pursestrings, so there's no point in trying to open it.
Rugan: I know a fence in Baldur's Gate who'll take it off your hands. Nobody will be the wiser.
Rugan: Don't try to cut me out of the deal though. The Black Network has eyes and blades everywhere.
Rugan: Crafty swine like you could make a name for yourself in the Zhentarim. Make sure to drop by our hideout.
Rugan: Pass phrase at the door is 'little serpent, long shadow'. I'll tell my associates to expect you.
Player: I already met your friends - we didn't get along too well.
Rugan: And yet here you are. There's not many cause trouble in a Zhent hideout and walk away.
Rugan: I'd rather walk away too. So let's say our goodbyes, and speak no more of it.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: I don't wish to study, only to lift the curse on this land.
Malus Thorm: A curse? Nay, a cure that leads to the very pinnacle of being:
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Shadowheart: A stinging truth - but a truth nonetheless.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes even you, one who walks faithfully in her shadow. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The goddess has greater plans for me than to submit to your scalpels.
: True
Malus Thorm: Another absence is your fate? But if you are not here to be cured, how will my sisters learn?
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: I am but a fumbling squire before a master swordsman. Please, demonstrate so that I might learn.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
: True
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: You came. Such a shame.
NodeContext: a sad welcome. Rhyme is intentional and playful. Speaking softly
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: CURIOSITY KILLED ALL THE CATS IT WON'T BE SO KIND TO YOU
Narrator: *As the woman speaks, you hear a distant rattle of chains, and she winces in pain.*
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Ah the jailor will hear us. I shouldn't be talking to you. I must go. It's not kind to me.
Narrator: *The figure flickers and starts to dim from view. But you sense she could be convinced to return.*
Player: Please don't leave.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I can't leave, I can only suffer. But I'm supposed to do that in silence. Everyone here hates me for what I am.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I'm the thing that kills you, and the only reason you're alive. Made by a promise, undone by the truth. A handshake, a hug, the first beat of a newborn's heart.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I am Hope. What little is left of her.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: A GUTTERING CANDLE IN A UNIVERSE OF NIGHT

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I'm not much of a friend to anyone anymore. But I could use a friend myself. Do you want a friend to guide you through this madhouse?
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Shhhtttt, I hear the jailor, it hears me. It'll call Raphael. Make every question count. Make some of them count twice.
Lae'zel: This place must house our contract with Raphael. If Hope points the way, we might take it - and shred it.
: NodeContext: urgent hushing and frantically getting out all of her words as quickly as possible. She's hushing the player, even though she was the one speaking

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: EXCEPT HE'S NOT HOME I'M INDISPOSED AND YOU'RE IN HELL
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Don't waste any more words, or we'll both be sorry.

Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: A student, yes. Do please enlighten me.

Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Wyll: Hells. Only a monster would inflict misery and call it medicine.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.

Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Discovered an ancient gith prince in need of a saviour? The Orphic Hammer is the perfect tool for breaking all infernal chains.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: May Shar guide your blessing hands.
Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours.
Malus Thorm: Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Darkness.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Lae'zel: Only a beast of a man toys with his victim. Entertaining, if not efficient.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure.
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The goddess has greater plans for me than to submit to your scalpels.
: True
Malus Thorm: Another absence is your fate? But if you are not here to be cured, how will my sisters learn?
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Practice - that's how I got good with a blade. They should spar each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: I am not worthy! Please, show me how a master works - I would be honoured.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
: True
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

Karlach: Ah! A circus! Can we go?!

Klaus: The Absolute's little murderers wouldn't dare.

Player: You can smell the blood of my enemies, that is all. Want to join my scent?
Player: Let me in, or I snap you in two.

Havkelaag: Well met. What can the Society of Brilliance do for you?
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: So the child inside will be experimented on?
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: This experiment is exactly the kind of evil you're trying to disprove.
Havkelaag: The pursuit of knowledge is neither evil nor good. Only in the application of such knowledge should one take on any moral imperative.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: An experiment like this will only confirm the surface dwellers' suspicion of us.
Havkelaag: Of course it won't. If anything, it will do quite the opposite. The academic institutions up here will finally be forced to take us seriously.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.
Havkelaag: Ah. Unfortunately, it seems I've mislaid my purse.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?
Player: Fine. Here you go.

Counsellor Florrick: ... unless darker forces are at work.

Alfira: They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.

Alfira: How do you do it? How do you keep going?

Alfira: You're made of sterner stuff than me then.

Narrator: *As you get closer to the printworks, something odd happens. You hear it speak.*

Printing Press: Are you addled in the head? I am no chattering contraption, I am a person. An artist. Name's Jelliwig.
Printing Press: This is my paintbrush. I make sure everything that's in those big ugly article blocks becomes fine printed artistry. I'm a master pensman, I am.
Printing Press: Now scram it. One mistake and the reputation of Baldur's Mouth Gazette crumbles to dust.
Player: I agree. The right words at the right time - literal magic. We're alike, you and I.
: True
Printing Press: Ahah, someone who appreciates the art of words. And a celebrity to boot. You'll enjoy this.
Printing Press: As it happens, the next edition has an article about you. Ooh, it's a mean one, too - real nasty. Ettvard must really have it out for you. Hard luck.
Printing Press: Will require a delicate touch to spruce up. Think I'll need my number seven pen. Real sharp.
Player: You need to stop it from being printed.
Printing Press: I'm afraid I can't help you. I've got a good thing going here - letting you swap out a whole article might get Ettvard suspicious.
Printing Press: I wouldn't take it too personal. Ettvard gets his lines from up top, then gets all worked up over it.
Printing Press: Although, it not being personal doesn't change how shafted you'll be.

Printing Press: A-ha! A meddler after my own heart - wonderful.

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.
Balthazar: I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Judging by how you're cowering in here, your survival?
Balthazar: I do not cower - I plan. I command. I create.
Balthazar: General Thorm trusts me. He knows I will deliver. He knows I will stand by him long after all others wilt and fall.
Balthazar: You and all the rest have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.
Balthazar: You, Z'rell, all the rest... you have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.
Player: Yet you seem no closer to retrieving the Nightsong? I read your notes - very interesting.
Balthazar: Interesting, and private. Give me one reason why I shouldn't have my creations kill you right now, thief.
Player: Do it - unleash your creations. But they will not protect you from me - or my righteous fury.
Player: You're hiding from shadows - literally. Don't make threats you can't back up.
: True

NodeContext: A pause before 'fine' - weighing up the player's fate.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is my finest creation - if I never exceed myself, I will still die happy. Not that I ever intend to do something as gauche as truly dying, of course.
Balthazar: Now, given your prying nature, I have work for you, as a scout.
Balthazar: The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.

Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you.
Balthazar: The relic is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes.
Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_HaarlepDouble: Hmmmm... you are so, so delicious.

Narrator: *As she continues to lavish herself upon your helpless form, you stop breathing, your heart stops beating, and your mind begins to clear entirely.*
Narrator: *Some last thought whispers in your skull, vacated by everything else but rapture -*
Narrator: *'This is the end.'*
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_HaarlepDouble: Devote yourself to pleasure eternal. Stay here with me - this can be forever.
Player: Try to cool your desires, and push the creature away.
: False
Narrator: *Try as you will, every part of you craves to melt right into him.*
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_HaarlepDouble: Devote yourself to pleasure eternal. Stay here with me - this can be forever.
Player: You can have my body, but not my mind.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_HaarlepDouble: A brilliant choice.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_HaarlepDouble: Vow that your body belongs to me.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_HaarlepDouble: Give yourself to me, and I will tell you what you wish to know.
Player: Pleasuring thousands with my body? I'd rather die.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_HaarlepDouble: Then, this will have been the very last time you experienced pleasure. Time for the BIG death.

He Who Was: Where lies your guilt?
NodeContext: Shadar-Kai speaks in a cold, calculated tone.
Madeline: The... Waning Moon...
NodeContext: Speak with dead style
Player: That spell - Speak With Dead, correct? Your technique is impeccable.
He Who Was: When you have lived as long as I, such simple magic becomes second nature.
Raven: *CAW.*
He Who Was: A fair point - perhaps this one could assist us.
He Who Was: The murdered lie silent. The raven asks - will you be their voice?
: True
Narrator: *The raven, the piercings, the general malaise: this is a shadar-kai. Tales and songs featuring servants of the Raven Queen tend to be tragedies.*
Player: Why does the raven want to know?
He Who Was: He thinks you strong enough for the task at hand.
He Who Was: This woman tended a bar where she took her patrons, her friends, into her confidence - promised their secrets were safe with her.
He Who Was: Yet she turned their words into knives - and stabbed them in the back.
He Who Was: They died because of her - and to this day her victims lie unavenged.
Player: It sounds like she must be punished - thoroughly.
He Who Was: You see it as I do.
He Who Was: I seek a record of this one's crimes - written in her own hand.
He Who Was: Through it, I can summon her spirit - and force her to face trial for her crimes.
Player: Hardly a fair trial - you've already decided her guilt. Why?
He Who Was: Will you take it?
Player: I will - what must I do?

Crusher: Wait! I - I yield! I yield!
NodeContext: Very panicked. They were in a fight he thought he'd win, but he's losing.
Lae'zel: Take his head. He won't be putting it to good use.
Player: Now. You should kiss my feet.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: May Shar guide your blessing hands.
Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours.
Malus Thorm: Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Loss.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Gale: Gods, what living nightmare is this?
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The goddess has greater plans for me than to submit to your scalpels.
: True
Malus Thorm: Another absence is your fate? But if you are not here to be cured, how will my sisters learn?
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Practice - that's how I got good with a blade. They should spar each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: I am but a fumbling squire before a master swordsman. Please, demonstrate so that I might learn.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
: True
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

Karlach: Hold up. One more step, and I put a bolt through your eye.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: stands, holding the crossbow in one hand, her other hand pressed to a wound on the left of her stomach. She appraises the player.
Karlach: No sudden movements, or you're dead.
Karlach: You looking for me?
Player: No, but I see you're hurt - let me help.
Karlach: Hurt or not, I won't miss - lung, heart, arse or eye. Take your pick.
Karlach: Tell me what you're doing here. Now.
Player: HERE TO KILL YOU. SLOWLY.
: True
Karlach: If you bite as hard as you bark, we might just get along. I'm dangerous all right, but I've got no quarrel with you.
Karlach: I reckon you've been sold a crock of shit about me.
Karlach: Don't sweat it - devils are tricky fuckers. They can't breathe without lying.
Player: Hold on - the people I spoke to were paladins, not devils.
Karlach: Sure they were - and I'm Tiamat's left tit.
Karlach: I guess they told you I bite the heads off babies, and paint myself in their blood.
Karlach: Truth's not quite so exciting. Come on over and I'll tell you the whole story.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~[reuse]The player approaches Karlach
Karlach: I'm a fugitive - escaped from the Hells, and those bastards are trying to take me back.
Player: You were in hell? So was I, not long ago.
Karlach: Really? You're serious?
Narrator: *As she winces, agony shoots through you, as if your bodies share the same wound.*
Narrator: *Then you're lost in visions of demonic armies, as you tear through a landscape of fire and blood.*
Narrator: *The Blood War. You saw it from above as the nautiloid passed through Avernus - this woman was on the frontline.*
Karlach: Ster'ca. What was that? You were inside my head...
NodeContext: ster'ca (stir-KA (very harsh KA)) is a curse word in infernal language. She's shocked, a little afraid of us
Player: It wasn't me - it's the parasites from the mind flayer ship. They connected us.
Karlach: Hold on a minute - you were on that ship? With the tentacles, and the worms?
Karlach: I didn't think anyone else had survived.
Player: You must have got clear of the crash site in a hurry.
Karlach: You're lucky I did.
Karlach: The place would have been crawling with cultists if I'd stuck around - and they'd have dragged us all back to Avernus.
Karlach: You gave me some breathing room when you killed those imp-fuckers, but more will come.
Player: Why are you so important to them?
Karlach: Most souls in the Blood War are just meat for the grinder, but not me.
Karlach: Devils don't like to lose their assets.
Player: Why don't you just run?
Karlach: They're not the kind of people you can run from. I need them dead.
Player: I'll take them down.

Withers: We meet again, as predicted.
Withers: I shall be here in thy camp, for whenever thou hast need of my services.
Player: Not to be rude, but what are you?
Withers: There are many answers to that question. None are important.
Player: Skeletons aren't supposed to be able to talk.
Withers: Correct.
Player: Are you going to explain further?
Withers: No.
Withers: No.
Player: You were sorting something before. What were you doing?
Player: Impressive. Are there other ways you can help us?
Withers: Should thou or any of thy compatriots perish, I will cleave soul to body once more.
Player: That's incredibly powerful magic. Why is it so easy for you?
Withers: Because it is my calling. There is little else to explain.
Player: I could use those resurrection services right now.
Withers: Then thou must return with the proper payment.
Player: I want to resurrect [CAMP_Jergal_PlayerToResurrect_1_c85cdca4-6579-776d-206d-6967e4999281].

Isobel: Hold - who are you, and what are you doing here?
Narrator: *Your body yearns to kill this cleric, more than anything else. You know it, deep down, in your writhing intestines.*
Player: My blood... it's telling me to kill you.
Isobel: And yet you hesitate.
Narrator: *She doesn't believe you will do it. You can see, she wants to believe there is mercy in all, even in the worst.*
Isobel: You aren't the first to threaten me. But I know the eyes of a killer when I see them. You mean me no harm. Do you? An experienced cleric can tell such things.
Narrator: *The Urge within does not want to talk. The restless Urge starts to scream.*
Player: Chase away your putrid desires.
Narrator: *As suddenly as it started, you have tamed the Urge. It slumbers again.*
Isobel: There we are. The real you. Your - affliction, is it? - doesn't rule you, does it.
Player: I'm not going to follow my order. You will live.

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.
Balthazar: I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Judging by how you're cowering in here, your survival?
Balthazar: I do not cower - I plan. I command. I create.
Balthazar: General Thorm trusts me. He knows I will deliver. He knows I will stand by him long after all others wilt and fall.
Balthazar: You and all the rest have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.
Balthazar: You, Z'rell, all the rest... you have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.
Player: Fine, consider your merits acknowledged. Care to enlighten me as to what's going on?
Balthazar: There is a relic here. One which General Thorm desires. No - needs. I will retrieve it for him...
Balthazar: ...and you will help me. Ignorant you may be, you've shown some prowess in scouting and combat by making it this far.
Balthazar: While you, an infinitely more humble servant, fulfil my command. I will put you to work - as a scout.
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him could be just what you need to gain access to the man himself.*
Player: So you need my help - what would I have to do?
Player: What do you need me to do?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you.
Balthazar: The relic is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes.
Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: You have resources to spare - give me something to aid my search.
: True
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell...
Balthazar: ...and he will come.
Balthazar: My brother is no intellectual powerhouse, but he is strong, loyal and punctual. Should a fight turn against you, remember the bell.
Player: Actually, I have your mother.
Balthazar: What the...? Give me back my mother, this instant!
Player: No, I think I'll keep her.

Acolyte Marls: I'm afraid you missed the ship, True Soul.
Acolyte Marls: But there'll be another along soon enough. We're already stacking the cargo.
Player: What cargo?
Acolyte Marls: Nothing of note. Just supplies for the battle ahead - I've already checked it twice over.
Narrator: *A strange symbol glows, marked on their flesh, and something within you stirs in response.*
Narrator: *As the symbol glows, power courses through you. Authority.*
Player: Then you won't mind stepping aside and letting me look.
: True
Narrator: *A shiver runs across your mind... You feel sated.*
Narrator: *As you bear down on his mind, you feel a pulse in response. A thousand pulses, echoing from the nearby crates.*
Narrator: *Tadpoles. His mind had rejected the knowledge, forced it behind a mental wall. A wall you just took a hammer to.*
Acolyte Marls: W-worms. Worms in their heads. Worms all over!
NodeContext: Breathless, near-catatonic with shock
Player: You had best wash them off.
Acolyte Marls: P-parasites! Worms!
NodeContext: Breathy, panicked - you've broken his mind a little

Havkelaag: Ah, a surface dweller.
Havkelaag: You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to the Underdark: the Society of Brilliance.
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I met an expeditioner claiming to work for you. She sought a githyanki egg.
Havkelaag: Yes, dear Lady Esther. One of our most reliable contractors, though unfortunately this particular request was too much even for her.
Havkelaag: I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you've stumbled across any githyanki eggs during your travels? The Society will compensate you for any we purchase, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You assume my people are evil, yet your research is built on sheer superstition.
Havkelaag: Enough of your kind have wreaked destruction on this plane for me to be confident in my assertion.
Havkelaag: When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: That kind of indoctrination and time-forced nurture violates the natural order. It invalidates the whole experiment.
Havkelaag: I won't bother to argue with you. An arboreal shaman can't be expected to understand the rigorous protocols of theoretical research.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: An experiment like this will only confirm the surface dwellers' suspicion of us.
Havkelaag: Of course it won't. If anything, it will do quite the opposite. The academic institutions up here will finally be forced to take us seriously.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.

Gerringothe Thorm: WHAT DO YOU BRING?
NodeContext: a desperate, cacophonous howl
Player: I will bring an end to the curse that shrouds this land.
Gerringothe Thorm: I REQUIRE GOLD.

Player: I don't hand out so much gold for so little in return.
Gerringothe Thorm: YOU MAY PASS THE RIVER. BUT FIRST YOU MUST PAY.
Player: I've already paid.
Gerringothe Thorm: YES! AGAIN!
Player: Gold is such a limited desire. With the right help, you could become so much more.
Player: Why stay in this rotted building? Take your gold and be free.
: True
Gerringothe Thorm: THE GOLD IS NOT FOR ME. THE GOLD IS FOR THE TOLL. I COLLECT THE TOLL. I COLLECT THE GOLD.
Player: Haven't you heard? The local authority has decreed the gold belongs to the toll collector - you.
: True
Gerringothe Thorm: ME? NO! GOLD! GOLD... GOLD...
Gerringothe Thorm: NO. I PAY IT BACK!

Shadowheart: Doing the rounds, are you? You'd better get some rest.
Shadowheart: What were you two talking about?
Shadowheart: What were you two talking about?
Player: What do you mean?
Shadowheart: You and that githyanki.
